title: freedomgo
author: freedomgo
content: It’s truly upsetting how these scammers operate without any sense of morality, even targeting individuals dealing with serious health challenges. But before we proceed, let's define first what is a Parkinson's disease...QuoteParkinson's disease is a movement disorder of the nervous system that worsens over time. The nervous system is a network of nerve cells that controls many parts of the body, including movement.So there it is, and it might get worse over time, especially since the victim is already 77 years old. Based on reports, elderly people are particularly vulnerable, they’re not tech-savvy and are often looking for opportunities to invest and grow their money. Others are scammed by people pretending to be authorities offering to “protect” their funds, which is exactly what happened in this case.Here’s the full story... https://nypost.com/2024/11/13/us-news/oklahoma-woman-with-parkinsons-disease-duped-out-of-20000-in-bitcoin-scam/QuoteAn elderly Oklahoma woman stricken with Parkinson’s Disease lost $20,000 in a cryptocurrency ploy that was crafted as a scam within a scam, according to her daughter.Jamie Moore, the daughter of 77-year-old scam victim Marsha, knew that a swindler had tried to reach out to her mother when she received an odd email about a Bitcoin transaction being finalized.“I received a text from my mom that said, ‘Jamie, I think I’m being scammed’ and I said, ‘Don’t fall for it, I get those emails all the time,’” Moore told KFOR.It was supposed to be smooth sailing from there since the duo had recognized the fraud.Then Marsha, who has Parkinson’s and Multiple Myeloma, reached out to the number listed in the phony email, looking for some clarity.She told the person on the other end that she had never made a Bitcoin purchase.The scammer, pretending to be a federal agent, told Marsha that her identity had been stolen and that she needed to make a withdrawal from her bank account to protect her money. He also told her to keep the situation a secret, including her daughter.“She was on the phone for probably five hours, he stayed on the phone with her,” Jamie said.Marsha followed the grifter’s instructions and made her way to the bank, where she even lied to the teller in order to justify the hefty $20,000 withdrawal.“She had been coached by this ‘FBI guy’ not to trust anybody and told the teller that she was having her house remodeled and she needed $20,000 — wiped out her entire savings account,” Jamie said.From there, the scammer told her to go to a liquor store 45 minutes away in Ponca City, Okla. to deposit her savings into a Bitcoin ATM.It wasn’t until Marsha had completed the transaction that she realized she had been duped.“I never thought it would happen to us and she’s humiliated, she’s embarrassed, she’s doubting her choices and she’s a smart woman, she’s bright and so it’s heartbreaking,” Jamie said.The family filed a police report, but there is little hope that Marsha will get her savings back.

comments.author: PrivacyG
comments.body: To be honest.  I do not understand how this can happen.  I keep repeating over and over, this is the type of person who has to get Scammed once to MAYBE only then finally realize people are not this helpful and happy to help out.  Particularly if it is a distance call, messaging et cetera.  The number of people STILL falling for the most basic and stupid Scams is out raging.How in the World did they think this was a situation SO important that the Federal Agent took FIVE HOURS of their time to work on it.  Say they wanted to help you out by suggesting that you Withdraw every single penny out of your Bank Accounts.  Why try to Deposit it some where else after that?I get it.  She was 77 years old and the human brain can do wonders some times, but other times it can play you so badly.  But then how she Trusted a completely stranger call to shut up and not say any thing to her daughter is beyond my understanding to be honest.  Unless the victim completely lost their mind.I do not know.  Very sad that this thing still happens so often.  And unfortunately I do really believe they will not get their Money back, unless they are lucky enough to have somebody find the Crimnal and return the Money to the victims.  Which I highly doubt.

comments.author: Sanitough
comments.body: Quote from: PrivacyG on November 17, 2024, 03:02:06 AMI get it.  She was 77 years old and the human brain can do wonders some times, but other times it can play you so badly.  But then how she Trusted a completely stranger call to shut up and not say any thing to her daughter is beyond my understanding to be honest.  Unless the victim completely lost their mind.She probably panicked and lost her focus, thinking her money was in danger. So when the person pretending to be an FBI agent told her to keep it secret, she agreed. In short, that call made her lose trust in her bank and instead trust the stranger on the phone, who was likely very convincing, as scammers often are. It’s almost like she was hypnotized.These scammers really are experts at what they do so elderly individuals or those unfamiliar with these types of scams are easy targets. It’s a sad story, really. That’s why we can’t blame the government for enforcing strict KYC regulations as they’re necessary to improve the chances of tracing and stopping the people behind these scams.

comments.author: Fiatless

Some years ago my mother bought land without the necessary documents because she thought she could handle the deal. We are still engaging in litigation to recover the property.

comments.author: hugeblack
comments.body: These scammers are willing to do anything to steal a dollar, let alone $20,000, but this scam can happen with any type of investment, maybe she needed more money and the scammer told her that there is an opportunity to double that $20,000 by investing in Bitcoin. The whole story worked out because of luck, the teller could have asked her daughter why her mother suddenly spent this amount or her daughter noticed that she was going to travel a long distance by car. And some questions like why the Bitcoin was purchased through an ATM and did she send the scammer the Bitcoin or ATM have back doors.

Why do you think scammers usually target people from that age group? It's because the success rate tends to be higher. If a scammer tries to pull the same scam with someone younger, let's say the daughter in this story, she would barely listen to anything he says and hang up because she would know it's a scam.This is not the first time an elderly person has been scammed. I have read and seen hundreds of such stories of people above 60 or 70 getting scammed. The reason is simple and it is that things we understand are not right might not sound the same to them, especially if they are not very tech-savvy or have some sort of disease to support the scammers in their mission further.It's unfortunate, and shouldn't happen, but the harsh reality is, it will, with someone else from another state, or country.

I hope this will not worsen the health condition of this old woman and make her die before the right time.
